title: Bharatendu Academy of Dramatic Arts
text:
Bharatendu Academy of Dramatic Arts or Bharatendu Natya Akademi is a theatre training institute in <a href="Lucknow">Lucknow</a>, India. It is named after <a href="Bharatendu%20Harishchandra">Bharatendu Harishchandra</a>, father of <a href="Hindi%20theatre">Hindi theatre</a>. It offers a two-year full-time diploma course in theatre training. It is an autonomous organisation under the Ministry of Culture, <a href="Government%20of%20Uttar%20Pradesh">Government of Uttar Pradesh</a>.
History.
Bharatendu Natya Academy came into existence as a drama institute on 2 July 1975, by efforts of the theatre personality <a href="Raj%20Bisaria">Raj Bisaria</a>.
In 1975 its name was Bharatendu Natya Kendra and the class was running at the mini Rabindralay (near Lucknow Railway Station). At that time BNA did not have their own building; now it functions from the Bharatendu Bhawan in <a href="Gomti%20Nagar">Gomti Nagar</a> (Vikas Khand-1). <a href="Lucknow">Lucknow</a>.
In 1981 the institute started providing a two-year full-time diploma course in theatre training. The institute today selects 20 candidates every year for its two-year intensive post-graduate diploma course with scholarships for the first 12 students. <a href="Raj%20Bisaria">Raj Bisaria</a> was the founder-director. Hindi writer <a href="Amritlal%20Nagar">Amritlal Nagar</a> was the first nominated chairperson of the institute. Today Bharatendu Natya Academy has become the second of its kind in India after the <a href="National%20School%20of%20Drama">National School of Drama</a>, New Delhi. At the end of their course, the second-year students make a visit to the <a href="Film%20and%20Television%20Institute%20of%20India">Film and Television Institute of India</a>, <a href="Pune">Pune</a> or <a href="Satyajit%20Ray%20Film%20and%20Television%20Institute">Satyajit Ray Film and Television Institute</a>, <a href="Kolkata">Kolkata</a> for the basic training for film and television. This is a kind of extension program is done with the financial support of Film Bandhu (a body under the Cultural Department of the U.P. Government).
